sentence-detokenized: EU rejects German call for boycott of UK lambs
Peter Blackburn.
Brussels 1996-08-22
The European Commission announced on Thursday that it disagrees with German advice to consumers to avoid lamb from the UK until scientists determine whether mad cow disease infects sheep.
Werner Zwingmann, the German representative on the European Union Veterinary Committee, said on Wednesday that consumers should buy lamb from outside the UK until scientific advice is clearer.
Commission chief spokesman Nicolas van der Pas told a press conference that 'we do not support such a recommendation because it has no basis'.
He said that further scientific research is needed and that if measures are found to be necessary, this should be done by the EU.

Last month, EU Agriculture Commissioner Franz Fischler proposed banning sheep brains, spleens and spinal cords from the human and animal food chain, which he said was a very concrete and precautionary action to protect human health.
Mr Fischler proposed EU-wide measures following reports from the UK and France that sheep can be infected with bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease, under laboratory conditions.

However, Fischler agreed to review the proposal after the EU's permanent veterinary committee (mational animal health officials) questioned whether such a measure was justified as the risk to human health was slight.
Spain's Agriculture Minister Loyola de Palacio had previously accused Fischler of causing undue alarm by 'dangerous generalisations' at a meeting of EU agriculture ministers.
Only France and the UK agreed to Fischler's proposal.
The EU Scientific and Interdisciplinary Commission for Veterinary Medicine will review the issue early next month and make recommendations to the High Commissioner for Veterinary Medicine.
Scrapie, a brain disease similar to BSE, is thought to be transmitted to cattle via feed containing animal excrement, and sheep have been known to be infected for some time.

British farmers denied on Thursday that sheep posed a risk to human health, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb may affect consumers across Europe.
John Lloyd-Jones, president of the National Farmers Union of Wales (NFU), said on BBC Radio: 'What we have to be extremely careful about is how the rest of the world is led by Germany.

Vonn is leading efforts to protect public health after a UK report in March suggested that eating contaminated beef could lead to a disease similar to mad cow disease, leading to a loss of consumer confidence.
Germany imported 47,600 sheep from the UK last year, accounting for almost half of its total imports.
UK mutton, at 4,275 tonnes, accounted for about 10% of total imports.
A rare Hendrix song manuscript sells for about USD 17,000.
A rare early handwritten draft of a song by legendary US guitarist Jimi Hendrix sold for about USD 17,000 on Thursday at an auction of the late musician's favourite items.
A Florida restaurant bought Hendrix's draft of 'Ain't no telling' on London hotel letterhead at the end of 1966 for £10,925 ($16,935).
At the end of a concert in Nottingham, England, in January 1967, he threw the paper into the audience, where it was collected by a fan.
Buyers also bought 16 other items at auction by Cathy Etchingham, an ex-lover who lived with Hendrix from 1966 to 1969.
It included a black lacquer and mother-of-pearl inlaid box used by Hendricks to store his medicines, which was bought for £5,060 (USD 7,845) by an anonymous Australian purchaser.
Guitarist who died of a drug overdose in 1970, aged 27.
China and Taiwan said it would spoil the atmosphere of the talks.
Beijing 1996-08-22
China on Thursday accused Taipei of spoiling the atmosphere for the resumption of cross-Strait talks when Taiwan's Vice-President Lien Chuan visited Ukraine this week, infuriating Beijing.

Just hours after Chinese state media said the time had come for political talks with Taiwan, Foreign Ministry spokesperson Shen Guofang told Reuters. 'The atmosphere necessary for the talks to begin has been disturbed by the Taiwanese authorities.
State media reported that China's top negotiator with Taipei, Tang Shuwei, told a visiting delegation from Taiwan on Wednesday that it was time for the rivals to hold political talks.
'Now is the time for political talks between the two sides...
Thursday's international edition of the People's Daily quoted Tang as saying: 'It is about ending the state of hostility'.

In an interview with Reuters TV, Shen from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said he had read the report on Tang's remarks, but did not elaborate on why he thought the time had come to negotiate with Taiwan, which Beijing regards as a breakaway province.
China, which has long opposed all efforts by Taipei to raise its international profile, is furious that Taiwan's Vice-President Lien visited Ukraine this week.
China announces that the time has come for Taiwan talks.
Beijing 1996-08-22
China says it is time for political talks with Taiwan and that the rival island should take realistic steps towards that goal.

The Xinhua News Agency quoted Tang Shu-pai, vice-president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, as saying that consultations should be held to determine the time and format of the talks.
German July car registrations up 14.2% year-on-year.
Frankfurt 1996-08-22
The German Federal Motor Vehicle Office announced on Thursday that the number of first-time vehicle registrations in July this year was 14.2% higher than in the same period last year.
According to the Department, 356,725 new vehicles were registered in July 1996, of which 304,850 were passenger cars and 15,613 were trucks.
This represents an increase of 13.6% for passenger cars and a decrease of 2.2% for trucks compared to July 1995.
Motorbike registrations increased by 32.7% over the same period.
This growth is partly due to more Germans buying German cars abroad, while manufacturers say domestic demand is weak, according to the Federal Secretariat.
Almost all German car manufacturers increased their registrations.
Volkswagen AG received 77,719 registrations, slightly more than a quarter of the total.
Opel AG and General Motors jointly registered 49,269 vehicles, accounting for 16.4% of the total, putting them in second place.
In third place was Ford with 35,563 vehicles, or 11.7% of all registrations.
Only Seat and Porsche had fewer registrations in July 1996 than in July last year.
Seats recorded 3,420 compared to 5,522 in the same month last year.
Porsche registrations fell from 643 to 554.
The Greek Socialist Party has given the Prime Minister the go-ahead for elections.
The executive of the Greek Socialist Party has given Prime Minister Kostas Simitis permission to call for snap elections, the party's general secretary, Kostas Skandaridis, told reporters.
Prime Minister Costas Simitis will make a formal announcement after the Cabinet meeting on Thursday, Skandaridis said.

Israel downplays fears of war with Syria.
Colleen Siegel.
Jerusalem 1996-08-22
Israel's peace negotiator with Syria said on Thursday that the current tensions between the two countries appear to be a storm in a teacup.
Itamar Rabinovich, who was Israel's ambassador to Washington for negotiations with Syria, told Israel Radio that Damascus appeared to want talks rather than fighting.
"It seems to me that {(1) [MISC] Syria's priority} is still to negotiate.
Syrians are confused and no doubt nervous. But here in Washington, the general assessment is that this is essentially a storm in a teacup," he said.
Mr Rabinovich is about to complete his term as ambassador.
He will be replaced by Eliahu Ben-Eliezer, a former special envoy to Egypt and a right-wing politician from the Likud party.
Israel sent a message to Syria via Washington on Wednesday, promising peace and saying it wanted to start negotiations without preconditions.
However, Damascus accuses it of creating a dangerous atmosphere.
Syria on Wednesday accused Israel of launching a hysterical campaign against it after Israeli television reported that Damascus had recently test-fired a missile.
Arms purchases are stated to be for defensive purposes.

In an interview with Israel Radio, Israeli Foreign Minister Levy said, 'The message we sent to [Syrian President Bashar] Assad is that Israel is ready to enter peace talks at any time without preconditions'.
Tensions have been high since Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu took office in June and pledged to maintain the Golan Heights, which he took from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.
Israeli-Syrian peace negotiations have been stalled over the Golan since 1991, despite the previous government's willingness to make concessions on the Golan.
The last peace talks between the two sides took place in February.
"The voices coming from Damascus are not good ones, they are bad ones.
Media...
is full of worrying expressions and declarations...
'People who spread this artificial atmosphere are very dangerous because they can become prisoners of it,' says Levy.
"We expect Syria, if its face is towards peace, it will respond to Israel's message of entering peace talks, because that is our goal."
We do not want war, God forbid.
No one gains from war."
Israel's Channel Two TV said Damascus had sent a 'calming signal' to Israel.
The source is not disclosed.
Spokespeople for Prime Minister Netanyahu and Prime Minister Levy said they could not confirm this.
The TV also stated that Prime Minister Netanyahu sent a message of reassurance to Syria through Cairo, the US and Moscow.
Polish diplomat denies nurses left behind in Libya.
Polish diplomats on Thursday denied reports in Polish tabloids this week that Libya was denying exit visas to 100 Polish nurses seeking to return home after working in the North African country.
"This is not true.

To date, we are not aware of any nurses being left behind in Libya or held against their will, and we have not received any complaints," Tadeusz Audankiewicz of the Polish Embassy in Tripoli told Reuters by telephone.

Poland's Labour Ministry announced this week that it would send a team to Libya to investigate, but Awdankiewicz said the investigation was prompted by some nurses' complaints about working conditions, including non-payment of salaries.
An estimated 800 Polish nurses work in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders meet in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafid
An Iraq-based Iranian exile group vowed on Thursday to increase its support for Kurdish rebels who were attacked by Iranian forces in deep Iraq last month.

A statement from the Mujahideen Khalq said that its leader, Masoud Rajavi, met with Hassan Rastegar, secretary-general of the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iran and Kurdistan (KDPI), in Baghdad on Wednesday and expressed support for the Iranian rebel Kurds.
"Rajavi stressed that the Iranian Resistance will continue to stand alongside its Kurdish brethren and the resistance movement in Iranian Kurdistan".
A spokesperson for the organisation said the meeting 'represents a new level of cooperation between the Mujahideen Khalq and Iran's Kurdish opposition'.
In July, Iran heavily bombed targets in northern Iraq in pursuit of KDPI guerrillas based in Kurdish areas of Iraq not under Baghdad government control.
The Kurdish areas of Iraq bordering Iran are under the control of guerrillas from the Iraqi Kurdish group Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK).
The PUK, Iraq's two main Kurdish factions, and the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iraq (KDP) have controlled northern Iraq since the 1991 Gulf War, when Iraqi troops were expelled from Kuwait.
Clashes between the two sides erupted over the weekend in the most serious fighting since last year's US-backed ceasefire.
According to Mujahideen Khalq, Iranian forces have also shelled KDP strongholds in the Kasli area of Sulaimaniya province, close to the Iranian border, over the past two days.
Around 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or wounded in the attack.
Both Iran and Turkey have been pursuing their own Kurdish rebels and have carried out air and land strikes on targets in northern Iraq.
The US-led air force in southern Turkey is protecting Iraqi Kurds from a possible attack by Baghdad forces.
The Saudi Riyal market has held firm in quiet summer trading.
Saudi dealers said the Saudi spot exchange rate against the dollar and the Riyal interbank deposit rate were mainly stable this week in quiet summer trading.
"The Saudi Riyal rate has not changed.
One dealer said that the market was very quiet because of the summer holidays.
The spot riyal was placed at 3.7504 / 06 to the dollar.
One-month interbank deposits were 5-1/2 and 3/8%; three-month deposits were 5-5/8 and 1/2%; and six-month deposits were 5-3/4 and 5/8%.
One-year funds were 6, 5-7/8%.
Israel approves Arafat's flight to the West Bank.
Jerusalem 1996-08-22
On Thursday, Israel allowed Chairman Arafat to fly from its territory to the West Bank, ending a brief crisis between Israel and the PLO, according to Arafat.
"Problem solving" is over.
The presidential plane has permission to fly through Israeli airspace, but the president is not expected to move to the West Bank before Monday," Nabil Abu Rhodaina told Reuters.

Chairman Arafat was due to meet former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in the West Bank town of Ramallah on Thursday, but changed the venue to Gaza after Israel refused permission to fly the Palestinian leader's helicopter.
Palestinian authorities accused right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of trying to stop the Ramallah talks by stalling Arafat.
Arafat subsequently cancelled a meeting on civil affairs between Israeli and PLO officials at the Allenby Bridge linking Jordan and the West Bank.
Abu Rdainah said Arafat had a busy schedule in Gaza and was not free until Monday, so he decided against flying to the West Bank on Thursday after Israel lifted the ban.
Arafat meets Peres in Gaza after flight ban.
Jerusalem 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat is due to meet Shimon Peres in Gaza on Thursday after the Palestinians said the right-wing Israeli government had banned the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank for talks with the former Prime Minister.

At a press conference on 2 November, Finance Minister Wataru Kubo indicated that the BOJ's interest rate policy to ensure economic growth has not changed following the release of the central bank's Tankan report.
